content: The country had had a bellyful of George Bush, Dick Cheney, and the rest of the messengers of darkness in Washington who had sold out the principles of the Republican Party in favor of huge deficits, a doubling of the national debt, and a growing intrusion of the federal government into people's private lives. But instead of getting on board the change train and recognizing the incredible amount of damage their people had done to the country, Republicans go blithely along as though nothing has happened. They're busy obstructing Obama's programs and criticizing the Democrats' spending plans that are aimed at trying to bring the country out of a horrible recession. I hate to break it to them, but a lot has happened. And they're not going to like any of it. The latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll shows the Republican Party's favorability rating at an all-time low. President Obama's is at an all-time high. The same poll shows that Republicans are getting most of the blame for the partisanship that hinders governmental progress. And perhaps most telling, when asked which party is best equipped to lead the country out of recession, the Republicans trail the Democrats by a stunning 30 points. And while all this is going on, the GOP ran a straw poll on who the party's nominee should be for president in 2012. Ready? Mitt Romney finished first followed by Bobby Jindal, Ron Paul and Sarah Palin. The Republican Party is marching double-time down the road to irrelevance and they don't even know it. Jack Cafferty, Commentary: GOP becoming a cartoon 3/10/09

content: quote: Originally posted by FrJohn1123: The country had had a bellyful of George Bush, Dick Cheney, and the rest of the messengers of darkness in Washington who had sold out the principles of the Republican Party in favor of huge deficits, a doubling of the national debt, and a growing intrusion of the federal government into people's private lives. But instead of getting on board the change train and recognizing the incredible amount of damage their people had done to the country, Republicans go blithely along as though nothing has happened. They're busy obstructing Obama's programs and criticizing the Democrats' spending plans that are aimed at trying to bring the country out of a horrible recession. I hate to break it to them, but a lot has happened. And they're not going to like any of it. The latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll shows the Republican Party's favorability rating at an all-time low. President Obama's is at an all-time high. The same poll shows that Republicans are getting most of the blame for the partisanship that hinders governmental progress. And perhaps most telling, when asked which party is best equipped to lead the country out of recession, the Republicans trail the Democrats by a stunning 30 points. And while all this is going on, the GOP ran a straw poll on who the party's nominee should be for president in 2012. Ready? Mitt Romney finished first followed by Bobby Jindal, Ron Paul and Sarah Palin. The Republican Party is marching double-time down the road to irrelevance and they don't even know it. content: While the Republicans are backed into a corner at the moment, they are far from extinct. What's interesting, is that the Democratic Party had been fairly incompetent when it comes to Presidential campaigns (although Obama has changed this trend); however, the Democratic party has benefitted from the neoliberal campaign that had spread its seeds years ago. Now, we are seeing the fruits of their labor. Having said that, 2010 will be an important year for the Republican party, and will likely be an indication of the near future, although they definitely will be back. There will always be an opposition, and the Republican Party has the resources to remain as the opponent of the Democratic Party. They might end up repackaged, but they'll be there nonetheless.

content: The country had had a bellyful of George Bush, Dick Cheney, and the rest of the messengers of darkness in Washington who had sold out the principles of the Republican Party in favor of huge deficits, a doubling of the national debt, and a growing intrusion of the federal government into people's private lives. But instead of getting on board the change train and recognizing the incredible amount of damage their people had done to the country, Republicans go blithely along as though nothing has happened. They're busy obstructing Obama's programs and criticizing the Democrats' spending plans that are aimed at trying to bring the country out of a horrible recession. I hate to break it to them, but a lot has happened. And they're not going to like any of it. The latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll shows the Republican Party's favorability rating at an all-time low. President Obama's is at an all-time high. The same poll shows that Republicans are getting most of the blame for the partisanship that hinders governmental progress. And perhaps most telling, when asked which party is best equipped to lead the country out of recession, the Republicans trail the Democrats by a stunning 30 points. And while all this is going on, the GOP ran a straw poll on who the party's nominee should be for president in 2012. Ready? Mitt Romney finished first followed by Bobby Jindal, Ron Paul and Sarah Palin. The Republican Party is marching double-time down the road to irrelevance and they don't even know it. Jack Cafferty, Commentary: GOP becoming a cartoon 3/10/09

content: While the Republicans are backed into a corner at the moment, they are far from extinct. What's interesting, is that the Democratic Party had been fairly incompetent when it comes to Presidential campaigns (although Obama has changed this trend); however, the Democratic party has benefitted from the neoliberal campaign that had spread its seeds years ago. Now, we are seeing the fruits of their labor. Having said that, 2010 will be an important year for the Republican party, and will likely be an indication of the near future, although they definitely will be back. There will always be an opposition, and the Republican Party has the resources to remain as the opponent of the Democratic Party. They might end up repackaged, but they'll be there nonetheless.

content: The country had had a bellyful of George Bush, Dick Cheney, and the rest of the messengers of darkness in Washington who had sold out the principles of the Republican Party in favor of huge deficits, a doubling of the national debt, and a growing intrusion of the federal government into people's private lives. But instead of getting on board the change train and recognizing the incredible amount of damage their people had done to the country, Republicans go blithely along as though nothing has happened. They're busy obstructing Obama's programs and criticizing the Democrats' spending plans that are aimed at trying to bring the country out of a horrible recession. I hate to break it to them, but a lot has happened. And they're not going to like any of it. The latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll shows the Republican Party's favorability rating at an all-time low. President Obama's is at an all-time high. The same poll shows that Republicans are getting most of the blame for the partisanship that hinders governmental progress. And perhaps most telling, when asked which party is best equipped to lead the country out of recession, the Republicans trail the Democrats by a stunning 30 points. And while all this is going on, the GOP ran a straw poll on who the party's nominee should be for president in 2012. Ready? Mitt Romney finished first followed by Bobby Jindal, Ron Paul and Sarah Palin. The Republican Party is marching double-time down the road to irrelevance and they don't even know it. Jack Cafferty, Commentary: GOP becoming a cartoon 3/10/09

content: While the Republicans are backed into a corner at the moment, they are far from extinct. What's interesting, is that the Democratic Party had been fairly incompetent when it comes to Presidential campaigns (although Obama has changed this trend); however, the Democratic party has benefitted from the neoliberal campaign that had spread its seeds years ago. Now, we are seeing the fruits of their labor. Having said that, 2010 will be an important year for the Republican party, and will likely be an indication of the near future, although they definitely will be back. There will always be an opposition, and the Republican Party has the resources to remain as the opponent of the Democratic Party. They might end up repackaged, but they'll be there nonetheless.

content: All this talk of extinction is quite funny, obviously no here pay attention to history much. I remember in 1999 / 2000 Rush, Hannity ect. said liberalism was dead in the US. They were wrong then and you libs are wrong now. Political and social trends have swung back and forth aprox every decade between Conservative and Liberal thought. Sometimes the party in charge over reached and pizzed off the electorate, sometimes circumstances fored the change. But instead of getting on board the change train and recognizing the incredible amount of damage their people had done to the country, Republicans go blithely along as though nothing has happened. They're busy obstructing Obama's programs and criticizing the Democrats' spending plans that are aimed at trying to bring the country out of a horrible recession. I hate to break it to them, but a lot has happened. And they're not going to like any of it. The latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll shows the Republican Party's favorability rating at an all-time low. President Obama's is at an all-time high. The same poll shows that Republicans are getting most of the blame for the partisanship that hinders governmental progress. And perhaps most telling, when asked which party is best equipped to lead the country out of recession, the Republicans trail the Democrats by a stunning 30 points. And while all this is going on, the GOP ran a straw poll on who the party's nominee should be for president in 2012. Ready? Mitt Romney finished first followed by Bobby Jindal, Ron Paul and Sarah Palin. The Republican Party is marching double-time down the road to irrelevance and they don't even know it. Jack Cafferty, Commentary: GOP becoming a cartoon 3/10/09 None of that crap matters now. Live in the present, not the past. Blaming others for the past will get you nowhere which is where you are going by denying the facts of the present. Frankly this Republican/Democrat war is about as childish as I've ever seen adults get. Get a grip people No No No, every chance Obama gets he makes sue he says he inherited this problem and that GB2 created it. His last BS was calling a reporter after the fact and whining that he is not a socialist and that he inherited this from the last Adm. Obama will you at least act like a President and grow up! I dont believe other presidents have done that. What? Every day on this board I listen to people ***** about Clinton, Regan, and Carter and how they are to blame for the way things are going on now. Pretty sure EVERY president blames the last administration, ever watch a debate? I didn't vote for Obama, but this election really brought out a lot of problems for the Republican party. Being an Independent, I feel I can comment with a lesser degree of bias since I disagree with about 60% of what the two main parties claim to stand for. The fact is that the GOP is in bad shape, no amount of Obama bashing is going to change that. I say this as someone who voted for McCain. The GOP's voter base is rapidly shrinking. They lost out in 2006 and 2008. The party keeps trying to recapture some conservative dream that never was, while most of the country is moving steadily towards the center, center-left. Laugh and disparage Obama all you want, but the facts are there in black and white. If you truly want to see Republicans regain some control in the next decade, a certain amount of self-critique is necessary.

content: The country had had a bellyful of George Bush, Dick Cheney, and the rest of the messengers of darkness in Washington who had sold out the principles of the Republican Party in favor of huge deficits, a doubling of the national debt, and a growing intrusion of the federal government into people's private lives. But instead of getting on board the change train and recognizing the incredible amount of damage their people had done to the country, Republicans go blithely along as though nothing has happened. They're busy obstructing Obama's programs and criticizing the Democrats' spending plans that are aimed at trying to bring the country out of a horrible recession. I hate to break it to them, but a lot has happened. And they're not going to like any of it. The latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll shows the Republican Party's favorability rating at an all-time low. President Obama's is at an all-time high. The same poll shows that Republicans are getting most of the blame for the partisanship that hinders governmental progress. And perhaps most telling, when asked which party is best equipped to lead the country out of recession, the Republicans trail the Democrats by a stunning 30 points. And while all this is going on, the GOP ran a straw poll on who the party's nominee should be for president in 2012. Ready? Mitt Romney finished first followed by Bobby Jindal, Ron Paul and Sarah Palin. The Republican Party is marching double-time down the road to irrelevance and they don't even know it. Jack Cafferty, Commentary: GOP becoming a cartoon 3/10/09

They're busy obstructing Obama's programs and criticizing the Democrats' spending plans that are aimed at trying to bring the country out of a horrible recession. I hate to break it to them, but a lot has happened. And they're not going to like any of it. The latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll shows the Republican Party's favorability rating at an all-time low. President Obama's is at an all-time high. The same poll shows that Republicans are getting most of the blame for the partisanship that hinders governmental progress. And perhaps most telling, when asked which party is best equipped to lead the country out of recession, the Republicans trail the Democrats by a stunning 30 points. And while all this is going on, the GOP ran a straw poll on who the party's nominee should be for president in 2012. Ready? Mitt Romney finished first followed by Bobby Jindal, Ron Paul and Sarah Palin. The Republican Party is marching double-time down the road to irrelevance and they don't even know it. Jack Cafferty, Commentary: GOP becoming a cartoon 3/10/09 The crusty old coot (Jack Cafferty) hits another one out of the park.

content: While the Republicans are backed into a corner at the moment, they are far from extinct. What's interesting, is that the Democratic Party had been fairly incompetent when it comes to Presidential campaigns (although Obama has changed this trend); however, the Democratic party has benefitted from the neoliberal campaign that had spread its seeds years ago. Now, we are seeing the fruits of their labor. Having said that, 2010 will be an important year for the Republican party, and will likely be an indication of the near future, although they definitely will be back. There will always be an opposition, and the Republican Party has the resources to remain as the opponent of the Democratic Party. They might end up repackaged, but they'll be there nonetheless.

Jack Cafferty, Commentary: GOP becoming a cartoon 3/10/09 None of that crap matters now. Live in the present, not the past. Blaming others for the past will get you nowhere which is where you are going by denying the facts of the present. Frankly this Republican/Democrat war is about as childish as I've ever seen adults get. Get a grip people No No No, every chance Obama gets he makes sue he says he inherited this problem and that GB2 created it. His last BS was calling a reporter after the fact and whining that he is not a socialist and that he inherited this from the last Adm. Obama will you at least act like a President and grow up! I dont believe other presidents have done that. What? Every day on this board I listen to people ***** about Clinton, Regan, and Carter and how they are to blame for the way things are going on now. Pretty sure EVERY president blames the last administration, ever watch a debate? I didn't vote for Obama, but this election really brought out a lot of problems for the Republican party. Being an Independent, I feel I can comment with a lesser degree of bias since I disagree with about 60% of what the two main parties claim to stand for. The fact is that the GOP is in bad shape, no amount of Obama bashing is going to change that. I say this as someone who voted for McCain. The GOP's voter base is rapidly shrinking. They lost out in 2006 and 2008. The party keeps trying to recapture some conservative dream that never was, while most of the country is moving steadily towards the center, center-left. Laugh and disparage Obama all you want, but the facts are there in black and white. If you truly want to see Republicans regain some control in the next decade, a certain amount of self-critique is necessary.
quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: quote: Originally posted by AngelHeart: quote: Originally posted by FrJohn1123: The country had had a bellyful of George Bush, Dick Cheney, and the rest of the messengers of darkness in Washington who had sold out the principles of the Republican Party in favor of huge deficits, a doubling of the national debt, and a growing intrusion of the federal government into people's private lives. But instead of getting on board the change train and recognizing the incredible amount of damage their people had done to the country, Republicans go blithely along as though nothing has happened. They're busy obstructing Obama's programs and criticizing the Democrats' spending plans that are aimed at trying to bring the country out of a horrible recession. I hate to break it to them, but a lot has happened. And they're not going to like any of it. The latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll shows the Republican Party's favorability rating at an all-time low. President Obama's is at an all-time high. The same poll shows that Republicans are getting most of the blame for the partisanship that hinders governmental progress. And perhaps most telling, when asked which party is best equipped to lead the country out of recession, the Republicans trail the Democrats by a stunning 30 points. And while all this is going on, the GOP ran a straw poll on who the party's nominee should be for president in 2012. Ready? Mitt Romney finished first followed by Bobby Jindal, Ron Paul and Sarah Palin. The Republican Party is marching double-time down the road to irrelevance and they don't even know it. Jack Cafferty, Commentary: GOP becoming a cartoon 3/10/09 None of that crap matters now. Live in the present, not the past. Blaming others for the past will get you nowhere which is where you are going by denying the facts of the present. Frankly this Republican/Democrat war is about as childish as I've ever seen adults get. Get a grip people No No No, every chance Obama gets he makes sue he says he inherited this problem and that GB2 created it. His last BS was calling a reporter after the fact and whining that he is not a socialist and that he inherited this from the last Adm. Obama will you at least act like a President and grow up! I dont believe other presidents have done that.
reply: What? Every day on this board I listen to people ***** about Clinton, Regan, and Carter and how they are to blame for the way things are going on now. Pretty sure EVERY president blames the last administration, ever watch a debate? I didn't vote for Obama, but this election really brought out a lot of problems for the Republican party. Being an Independent, I feel I can comment with a lesser degree of bias since I disagree with about 60% of what the two main parties claim to stand for. The fact is that the GOP is in bad shape, no amount of Obama bashing is going to change that. I say this as someone who voted for McCain. The GOP's voter base is rapidly shrinking. They lost out in 2006 and 2008. The party keeps trying to recapture some conservative dream that never was, while most of the country is moving steadily towards the center, center-left. Laugh and disparage Obama all you want, but the facts are there in black and white. If you truly want to see Republicans regain some control in the next decade, a certain amount of self-critique is necessary.
title: Double-timing down the road to irrelevance

content: quote: As a Conservative what I see is that the Republicans have gotten their wake up call, and that's going to turn into a good thing. Maybe that's what has Dems nervous? See I don't think conservatives have gotten the wake up call. Exhibit A: "News reports out today showing that PBHO has broken 4 of the 5 promises he made during his campaign in ways that no politician before him has broke their promises. His first one hundred days in office will seal his failure to get re-elected, and does anyone think Reid or Pelosi has a chance?? The dems next best candidate will be Cindy Sheehan" Republicans are doing now what Democrats did in 2000. Crying over spilt milk rather than trying to fix the glaring problems within their own party.
